The link is only to a two page summary of the study so it is hard to assess the study closely but here are some observations about what one can glean from the summary:

The study is of the same families in 1983 and 2007. So the members of those families were probably adults in 1983, meaning that their economic attribues and views were shaped by the forces of the earlier years which were obviously more advantageous to whites. It doesn't tell us anything about any other cohort. It may be an interesting bit of historical evidence about the effects of differences in the 60s and 70s, but it is not probative of what families starting out today can reasonably expect to experience.

The study excludes home equity, meaning it probably captures wealth in the form of financial assets. But it is my understanding that many African Americans have historically been distrustful of large financial institutions so that preference may have been a factor in the different returns over the years.

There is the issue of compounding. Discriminatory effects earlier on can compound over time even if the amount of discrimination in our society has declined since then.

It is impossible to identify causality / allocate responsibility for differences in performance for the outcomes in this study. There is probably evidence in the world to support every explanation, both those offered from the left and from the right. But that evidence is exogenous to this study which has historical value but no analytic value.

I definitely get the sense that the "new" jobs being added are crummy service jobs that pay less well than the jobs lost. Also, companies learn to be more efficient in down times. Why is it that college graduates and even some with advanced degrees can't get jobs other than at Pizza Hut? I know the legal field is in a never before seen slump. I hate to sound like Chicken Little, but I really believe our country is going to Hell in a hand cart, and I was employed and working through all the recessions reflected in the graph.

When Ronald Reagan convinced the simple-minded that there was a shortcut to prosperity called "supply-side economics", the G-20 nations all drank the kool-aid and started cutting taxes and running deficits to "stimulate growth".  Unfortunately, the ponzi scheme only worked if the deficits got progressively larger every year.  The final collapse and meltdown was inevitable and would obviously start at the weakest link in the chain (Greece).  Don't worry, our turn is un-avoidable now.

Greece's problem is not corruption of only elected officials. Pretty much everyone in Greece can be bought off - including the lowly tax man. No one in Greece pays their fair share of taxes and the dwindling public coffers are not a result of bad management, but due to the lack of effective tax collection. Dr's with Beverly Hills style mansions claiming they make 12,000 a year and paying taxes on such is just plain criminal. But putting millions of lying taxpayers in jail won't help. Greece needs tax reform and so does the US but for different reasons. In Greece no one pays tax because of corruption. In the US so few pay tax because of the system. With so few paying tax only those paying their fair share of tax should be allowed to complain. A much more liberal / fair and perhaps slightly socialist viewpoint, would be to make everyone pay their fair share of taxes. 1 way of doing this would be to enforce the tax regime / rules (in the Greek case) and for the US to introduce a VAT - or some other similar broad based low-rate consumption tax.
A good example of how to do this might be Canada with its GST model. All GST revenues generated by the federal government in Canada go towards (1) servicing and (2) paying off the federal debt. What an idea and what a great way for the US to loosen its ties to the Chinese and other foreign governments who hold the bonds.

The future is becoming too predictable, without any realistic alternative.  I fear for children like mine, only 15 and 18, who will come of age in a world seemingly constrained on all sides.  It surely feels that we have arrived at the dawn of America's inexorable decline.

A recovery I might add that has been compromised all the way by the financial industry with it's lobbyists, multi-million dollar advertising and special interest "loopholes", and the Republican party.

This is a global recession, and requires global action, and so far there have been too many periods of navel gazing and inertia, hoping that something will turn up, reminds me of Mr Micawber from 'Great Expectations'.."Welcome poverty!..Welcome misery, welcome houselessness, welcome hunger, rags, tempest, and beggary! Mutual confidence will sustain us to the end!"

The way out of the present Great Depression should have three axes:
1) a higher inflation target, around 4%. The European Central Bank targeted 1%, which is 1% removed from deflation, which is a trap with no exit.
2) government organized stimulus, New Deal style. It worked in the 1930s, in the USA and Germany.
3) national banks investing in the real economy (an old European trick now used by China and India)

Let's notice that Japan would be in depression, if not for massive government spending. Now, of course Japan has a total debt of 200% of GDP, nearly twice the one of Greece.

The crack about Greece not be ready for the euro is neither here nor there. The drachma was converted at the wrong rate. Moreover, the present crisis is made to bring the euro down to parity with the dollar quickly. Europe is punishing China and the USA for atrocious behavior at the Copenhagen climate conference. The euro is still more than 20% overvalued right now (mid May 2010). You may have to enjoy you future double dip, if you do not mind USA plutocracy more than you do the European Union.

The idea that some economic patchwork is going to salvage a sinking ship like the US is a bit fatuous. The globe's economy is built on a chimera called Free Market Capitalism, something which certainly hasn't existed in the USA ever (instead we have socialism in the form of half the US budget feeding an unnecessarily very bloated military-industrial complex; subsidies to corporate farmers; etc. etc.) and doesn't really exist anywhere. But, to feed this chimera and the system it demands, we must have constant growth or the whole illusion falters and collapses. Well, sorry, it doesn't work. Period. However there is in fact ample material wealth in the US to keep everyone nicely happy, fed, housed, etc. if we would merely consider another system, which might require mere self-sustaining agriculture, minimal material needs, and so on. However the filthy rich couldn't get richer this way, and the military-industrial complex would lose its raison d'etre, so this concept is not going to get anywhere until our communal collapse forces the issue. Sooner that we think?

You drew parallels between Japan, US, and Greece and you blamed euro for Greek debacle but Japan has always had a separate currency, so what actually went wrong?

Japan was wrong because it had floating exchange rates and Greece was wrong because it had fixed rates. US was wrong because the government did not print enough money. So who's right?

Following Paul's suggestions, US should follow the way the Chinese stimulate the economy-planning every part of the economy. Spending people's money out of their willingness and hence a sustainable boom would result.

Or perhaps print more and more money so every one can spend the way they like and nobody would ever want to work.

Or devalue the US dollar so that nobody in the world would like to hold dollar assets anymore. Perhaps when Paul goes to Zimbabwe, he would need to change into renminbi.

in fact, the only thing really missing is truly authentic leadership in this country. all the impostors in all 3 branches of government and all those in the private sector are ruining us and missing any opportunity.
Perhaps it is time to outsource our leadership as well, e.g. to china.

We do not have to look toward Japan or Greece to see our future.  The stock market is one of the best forward indicators and it is forecasting a grim economy.  This should come as no surprise.  Dubious health care reform legislation sucked the oxygen out of the room while the higher priority of putting Americans back to work languished.  History shows we will pay an awful price for this disturbing lack of judgment and leadership.

Yet another commentary ignoring the nearly trillion dollars per year elephant in the room - the US military expense. What is it going to take to get attention to this best of all opportunities for deficit reduction and security enhancement? We are less not more safe as the result of spending more on war making than all other nations combined.
Carl, Portland

Economists talking about the 'next' crisis or the problems of the 'next' ten years are missing the crisis that is taking place in the here and now.

Professor Krugman presents another article that doesn't mention energy. Unfortunately the relationship between oil and the US dollar makes the buck a defacto hard currency.

While monetary and fiscal actions can buy valuable time and allow for necessary restructuring, unless conservation takes hold these actions will have no effect.

The increasing real price of energy makes it more expensive than the commerce that is leveraged from it. The dollar is becoming a proxy for oil rather than a proxy for business activities. The outcome is accelerating deflation where the only escape is to cease using fuel.

Using fuel makes dollars more valuable. These representing fuel will be hoarded as each dollar represents what might be the last bit of gasoline or diesel. It's 'Mad Max' with a coat and tie.

Here's a list of countries ranked by share of public debt to GDP:
http://en.wikipedia.org...

Japan is the second highest indebted country in the world, after Zimbabwe and before Lebanon, Jamaica, Greece, Egypt et al. And you are saying Japan didn't spend enough?

Anyone who has actually been to Japan knows how poor Japan really is. The country feels like it's still stuck in the 1980s. There are evidence everywhere of massive government projects in Japan that only temporarily created jobs, but did nothing to make the economy run better in the long run.

Professor Krugman, it is your path that will make us another Japan.

It seems like only yesterday when Bush was sending out his stimulus rebate checks. How many years ago in this recession was that?

Enough of the schemes already.

Dude, I'm no economist, but speaking from the vantage point of a guy who's been out in the neighborhoods of my city, which currently suffers a poverty rate more than double the national figure, and an unemployment rate to match, along with housing stock that is deteriorating and increasingly vacant, I can tell you that you ain't seen nothin' yet.

Just wait until the real crunch comes....

You made it sound like Japan's lost decade was a disaster, which it wasn't. Japan built a much more energy efficient economy; they still have a trade surplus, meaning they make more for the rest of the world than they consume; they have the longest life span among major nations; they continue to contribute to science, innovate in engineering, create in culture and arts. So what is exactly wrong with Japan? Should they have grown more and consumed more stuff? Would that have made a better world or a better Japan? Yes Japanese population is declining, but that is starting from one of the highest density of population on earth. So that is not exactly an irrational outcome. What economists decry as horror (a stalling nominal GDP) is not necessarily horrible in real life. More government created busy work will not necessarily make our life better in the U.S. either.

The man in America who best represents the middle is President Obama. He is moderate in temperment, in his politics and in his policies. While people all around the country are pointing fingers, screaming and blaming others, Obama is quietly, confidently, and persistently moving the government and the country forward. He is to whom Ben should be looking and he is our best hope.

Ben doesn't think things through very well, does he?  Just as well he didn't major in history - he's clearly better working with his hands than his brains.  Ben assumes that because he and his friends had the same opportunities, everyone does.  His dogmatic credo that "if people do not work but get rewarded, that’s wrong" doesn't leave much room for the old or infirm, nor the innocent children of the people he seems to think are scamming the system at his expense.  Nor the people who worked just as hard as he did, and put their money into the market like everyone told them to, and faced the prospect that now that they needed their retirement savings, they were going to disappear along with a failed bank.

"In a few years’ time, Ben is going to look for something else. It will be interesting to see if, by that time, any moderates have had the foresight and energy to revive and define the free labor tradition — "

Actually, Ben is going to find a whole new set of incentives for labor, once he realizes that they have stolen his 401k, his social security and encouraged his penslon fund to invest all of his money in banks that are TBTF.

There will be a kind of fairness and equality - since all of those who made their pile by lying, cheating and stealing will wind up in the same shape.

I sympathize with Ben. In my first job in Chicago, I worked in the alleys for a fruit & vegetable salesman for $2. That's $2 a DAY, not an hour (plus about $2/day in tips), and it was a 14 hour day. I've worked in MANY manual jobs (one which exploited workers and caused long term back problems for me). I now regularly work a 14 hour day and a few hours on the weekend. I've saved and I've NEVER been in debt, except for a small school loan, I paid back ahead of when it was due. I believe in MODERATION in government. I'm not strongly left or right. I'm against militaristic PLUTOCRACY on the right, pretending it's conservatism, and socialism on the left, and I'm against unnecessary mega-expensive warfare, as in Iraq. Give me a moderate with similar opinions and I'll vote for him/her!

There are well organized groups with great influence over our foreign policy which want war, and will settle for nothing less. "Real men go to Tehran." It is far more than just an Israel Lobby, although that is part of it.

We need first of all to face this, that many of those in charge do not want any of the "goals" tossed about. Those are just ideas around which people might be rallied to war, and any idea will do, so long as it produces war with Iran.

As with Iraq, there are many who want war for many reasons, who do not even agree with each other except in this desire for a war with Iran. Until we face this for what it is, no good can be done. All sincere talk about the various rallying cries misleads and distracts.

No progress can be made in this matter - an impasse with the potential for global upheaval - until the United States is instrumental in bringing Israel's nuclear capability into the open. The abject dishonesty that permits such a ridiculous charade to continue cannot possibly be in anyone's best interests.
